对如何学习语言的回顾，涵盖六种流行的语言学习方法背后的证据。

研究表明什么是学习语言的最佳方法？首次出现在Scott H Young上。

;

语言学习是一个我很关心的话题。没有什么比用一种直到最近你还无法理解的语言与某人交谈更令人兴奋的了。但是，尽管当你学对语言时会令人兴奋，但学习一门语言也可能充满挫败感、误解和令人尴尬的错误。

我学习语言的大部分知识都来自第一手经验。在大学期间，我在国外学习法语的日子很坎坷。后来，我和朋友一起旅行时，在一年内学习了四种不同的语言，有了更好的体验。

尽管进行了多年的自我实验，我还没有仔细研究过哪些内容在语言学习中有效，哪些无效。最近，我决定开始通过阅读一些有关第二语言习得科学的书籍来解决这个问题。最好的是 Patsy Lightbown 和 Nina Spada 的《语言是如何学习的》。

评估六种不同的语言学习方法

Lightbown 和 Spada 的书是作为第二语言教师的培训指南，涵盖了广泛的语言习得研究。我发现这一章总结了六种流行的方法以及支持和反对它们的证据，这非常有趣。

1、准确第一。

翻译是语言教学的经典方法。学生们会得到词汇表和语法规则，并被要求翻译拉丁语或希腊语文本。虽然这对于欣赏古代文学可能很有用，但它与现代学生学习法语或西班牙语的交流目标相去甚远。

受行为主义心理学的启发，音频语言方法试图用呼叫和响应格式取代这种基于文本的方法。在这种新方法中，学生通过严格遵循老师的示例来产生正确的句子。通过从一开始就正确地教授这些模式，就不会养成不良的说话习惯。

准确性第一的方法长期以来在课堂上很流行。但在研究人员中，他们失宠了，因为他们的一些基本假设开始受到质疑：

  • 大多数语言的使用并不是严格意义上的模仿——我们会生成新的句子来表达我们的意思。听说方法的大量重复可能并不能反映我们如何获得真正的语言。
  • 语言（包括第二语言）是按照发展时间表出现的。无论教学方式如何，学生似乎都会按照固定的顺序学习某些语法模式。这表明避免所有错误实际上是不可能的。
  • 课堂学习与自发语言使用有着微妙的关系。书中提到了一项研究，在该研究中，被积极教授某种特定模式的学生确实更多地使用了该模式，但在其他句子中也犯了更多错误！

然而，也许最重要的是，诺姆·乔姆斯基对 BF Skinner 对语言的行为主义解释的毁灭性打击鼓励研究人员到其他地方寻找新方法。

2. 只需输入即可。

斯蒂芬·克拉申 (Stephen Krashen)是对“准确性第一”的语言学习方法最严厉的批评者之一。他的输入假设提出，语法练习和重复练习除了效率低下之外，在产生真正的语言习得方面也完全无效。

相反，克拉申的理论认为，你只需要可理解的输入来学习语言。在这里，输入是指你听或读的语言的含义，而不是试图分析其语法。因此，您为了理解而阅读的书籍、路标或对话都将被输入。你从课本上抄来的句子却不是。

基于输入的方法有其吸引力：练习并不是特别有趣，演讲机会可能稀缺且压力很大，但书籍和录音随处可见。一项研究甚至发现，在基于输入的课堂上学习两年后，学生的表现与传统课堂上的学生一样好（甚至更好），包括在口语方面的表现——尽管他们从未练习过。

然而，一些研究反驳了克拉申假说的一些更大胆的主张。对拥有大量语言输入的法语沉浸式学生的研究发现，尽管他们的理解能力达到了母语水平，但尽管经过多年的全日制沉浸式学习，他们在说话时仍然会犯非母语语法错误。学生似乎确实受益于对语言形式和规则的明确指导。

3. 说话就是一切。

语言学习的另一个理论是学生需要互动交流，而不仅仅是输入。 Merrill Swain 的输出假说翻转了 Krashen 的输入假说，认为表达更复杂想法的需要可能是语言学习的驱动力。同样，迈克尔·朗的互动假说认为，互动（而不仅仅是输入）对于学习至关重要。

基于交互的方法的优点之一是，对话伙伴可以自然地调整他们的沟通水平，以便学生能够理解。相比之下，书籍或录音是固定的，因此必须找到适当难度的材料。

另一个优点是，真正的交流可以让学生假设语言是如何运作的，并根据他们的成功获得即时反馈。相反，只强调输入或练习的方法不允许这种实验。

然而，纯粹的互动方法，缺乏语法指导，可能会更难养成正确的说话习惯。当对话伙伴的意思被理解时，对话伙伴通常不会纠正错误，并且当他们的错误话语被正确地重复给他们时，许多学生不会使用更微妙的反馈形式。

4. 业余学习一门语言。

时间是语言学习的主要限制。幼儿有数万个小时接触母语。即使是一个聪明的成年人，每周只用三十分钟的时间怎么能竞争呢？

解决这一困境的一种方法是将语言学习与其他学术目标结合起来。在这些课程中，语言不是作为单独的课程教授，而是作为其他课程的教学语言。

加拿大的法语浸入式项目就是最成功的例子之一。从幼儿园开始，英语学生接受的所有日常学术指导都是法语，而不是英语。到了 12 年级，他们不仅拥有接近母语的法语能力，而且在学习标准学术课程方面也与英语同学保持同步。

作者指出，作为一种语言学习方法，这些程序效果很好，但也存在一些缺点：

  • 学生可能需要几年的时间才能在新语言中取得良好的学术成绩，这表明当沉浸式课程开始较晚或学生没有足够的时间适应新的教学语言时，这种方法可能不起作用。作者列举了香港的浸入式英语课程，由于学生面临的学业压力，这些课程举步维艰。
  • 如前所述，如果学生没有足够的练习机会或没有足够重视语言本身的教学，沉浸式课程可能无法达到母语水平。

5、按正确的顺序学习。

20 世纪 80 年代末，曼弗雷德·皮内曼 (Manfred Pienemann)及其同事表明，语言规则不能简单地以任何顺序学习——第二语言学习者，就像孩子学习母语一样，以固定的顺序习得语法规则，而这种顺序不会随教学而改变。

根据这种观点，语言的某些特征，例如词汇，可以随时教授。其他功能——比如使用“did”这个词将一个句子变成英语中的一个问题，例如“你把它放在哪里？”——按照固定的发展顺序进行。

这种方法与第一种方法相矛盾——如果某些错误是由于无法跳过的发展转变造成的，那么不断地专注于纠正错误就会适得其反。

然而，作者认为，从这项研究中吸取的正确教训并不是语法不能从教学中受益，而只是最好按照学生自然进步的顺序进行教学。

6.“最终把事情做好。”

Lightbown 和 Spada 回顾了以前的方法以及数十年积累的研究，认为我们应该避免过去语言学习时尚的一些过度行为。

  • 与听说法不同，学生应该有机会从一开始就有意义地使用语言。
  • 然而，大多数学生不会关注纯粹的输入、交互或沉浸式方法，而是会发现对语言形式的关注有助于达到准确的言语水平。

作者回顾了许多研究，这些研究表明，只要明确地教授和练习这些模式，学生在使用特定模式时的表现就会显着提高。然而，同样明显的是，如果不花时间进行真诚的交流，真正的语言能力就不可能出现。

反思我的语言学习方法

阅读这些理论以及它们引发的激烈辩论很有趣，部分原因是我的语言学习方法并不完全适合其中任何一个。

我学习新语言的首选方法是在一段时间内“不使用英语”，将所有或大部分交流切换到新语言。这可能最接近交互主义范式，认为对话（而不仅仅是练习或输入）对于熟练程度很重要。

然而，根据我的经验，我也发现传统的语法练习、抽认卡和纠正反馈是关键。在我学过的每种语言中，我都做过这些练习。

我对语言学习的心理模型是，更正式的练习通常是首先学习新单词或语法模式的最佳场所，但需要真正交流的情况允许我在足够的上下文中重复这些模式，这样它们就变得毫不费力和自动的。只有在更加流畅的情况下，我才发现自己经常通过互动来学习新模式。

我以前可能低估了人们仅靠阅读和听力能走多远。我仍然没有皈依克拉申和他的追随者的信念，即应该避免演讲和指导。但是，研究表明，在口语成本高昂或不切实际的情况下，学生似乎无需太多口语练习即可获得口语能力，这一事实似乎很重要。

语言学习继续让我着迷（有时也令人沮丧），所以我喜欢阅读 Lightbown 和 Spada 对科学发现的深入讨论。

研究表明什么是学习语言的最佳方法？首次出现在Scott H Young上。

写你喜欢读的东西，不管别人怎么想，你都会拥有一些值得骄傲的东西。

我的第一条写作规则一文首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

我写了很多东西：超过1600 篇文章、五本书（如果包括最初直接发布到博客上的内容，则为十本）、无数的视频脚本、电子邮件通讯等等。

当然，数量并不能保证质量。我的写作还有很多需要改进的地方。希望经过几十年的实践，我能够做到这一点。但是，到目前为止，我至少可以声称拥有一些经验。

鉴于我的经历，崭露头角的作家偶尔会向我寻求建议。我通常的回答是写很多。在开始审查你的作品之前，先撰写并发表一百篇文章。对于大多数新作家来说，出版一些东西（即使只是在网上）的想法都让他们感到不知所措，所以克服这个障碍比巧妙地写散文更重要。

但假设你经常写作，你应该写什么？

写你喜欢读的内容

作为一名作家，我为自己遵守的唯一规则就是努力写出我喜欢读的东西。为自己写作听起来可能很自恋，但事实恰恰相反。如果你自己都不关心自己写的东西，为什么其他人要关心呢？

为自己写作可能比听起来更难。其一，我们喜欢阅读的内容通常比我们认为有能力创作的内容更聪明、更诙谐、更富有想象力、更发人深省。尤其是在刚开始的时候，品味通常会超过熟练程度。

为自己写作的第二个困难是，至少对于非小说类作品来说，我们喜欢阅读我们还不知道的东西。我们也不喜欢那些不知道自己在说什么的作家。因此，写你喜欢读的东西需要仔细审视你认为理所当然的想法和知识：如果你还不知道它所讨论的一切，你会如何判断这篇文章？

写你喜欢读的东西可以写出更好的散文。你讨厌反问句吗？不要使用它们。 1你喜欢作家以故事开头，还是希望他们能找到论证的证据？你喜欢短句吗？或者对主题进行细致入微的华丽描述是否更符合您的喜好？

没有“正确”的答案。写你喜欢读的内容。除此之外没有任何书面规则。

可能需要一些思考才能弄清楚你喜欢什么样的写作。第一印象可能会产生误导。我在学习我喜欢的写作时做过练习。通常，我认为自己喜欢的一篇文章，结果却根本不存在。当我重读一位我钦佩其研究深度的作者时，我发现这本书只包含少量的引用。

只有当你真正开始审视为什么某些写作对你有吸引力时，你才有希望在自己的作品中重新创造它。

为别人写作的危险

作家并不总是可以选择如何写作。出版物有自己的风格。企业演出希望你能与样板相匹配。科学期刊希望您的研究论文符合特定的模板。

因此，写你喜欢读的内容的建议必须始终在你选择发布的地方的限制范围内查看。然而，即使在那些有时会受到限制的束缚中，你也可以识别你喜欢的写作和你不喜欢的写作。

我们模拟他人思维过程的能力比我们通常想象的要差。 “我不喜欢这样，但某某会的”不仅是居高临下的态度，而且几乎总是错误的。人们可能喜欢与你不同的写作风格，但很少有人会在自己不喜欢的情况下对这种吸引力进行逆向工程。

写作的乐趣并不在于赚大钱或让人们称赞你的作品——这些事情很少见，即使是最优秀的作家也会感到沮丧。相反，这是写出你认为好的东西所带来的满足感。写你喜欢读的东西，不管别人怎么想，你都会拥有一些值得骄傲的东西。

我的第一条写作规则一文首先出现在Scott H Young上。

什么是自我效能以及成功实现具有挑战性目标的三个最重要的要点

这篇文章《自我效​​能感：理解你的动机的关键》首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

如果我只能推荐一个概念来学习动机心理学，那就是阿尔伯特·班杜拉的自我效能感概念。

自我效能有助于解释我们动机的许多谜题：

  • 尽管我们知道自己需要变得更健康，为什么我们还是放弃健身计划？
  • 为什么在考试日期临近时我们要把时间浪费在手机上而不是学习呢？
  • 为什么我们有时会因为接受新的挑战而感到兴奋，但有时却会退缩？

了解自我效能也可以帮助我们建立动力。但要理解这个理论，我们需要退后一步，看看自我效能旨在纠正的更早、更简单的动机理论。

理性预期：机器人的动机

理性期望是一个重要的动机理论，由爱德华·托尔曼和库尔特·勒温在二十世纪上半叶独立提出。

它提出，我们对动机的主观感受是对我们采取行动所经历的收益和成本的无意识计算。用数学来说：

动机 = 收益 x 概率 – 成本

举个具体的例子，根据理性预期，我对锻炼的动力来自于我期望达到的好处（健身），乘以锻炼带来这种好处的机会，减去坚持锻炼的努力成本到我的健身计划。

正如其名称所暗示的，理性预期就是理性的。这个理论表明，每当我们感到没有动力时，只是因为我们认为另一种选择对我们更有价值。因此，如果我们不锻炼身体，而是坐着看 Netflix，那么我们更看重的是继续观看节目，而不是拥有海滩般的身材。一点也不神秘。

理性预期并不是一个糟糕的理论——它可能很好地解释了我们在许多情况下为何会受到激励。但这也是我们期望机器人而不是人类的动机理论——它假设我们完美地权衡了选项并总是做出正确的选择。

人类的动机：自我效能感的干预

阿尔伯特·班杜拉 (Albert Bandura) 认为，理性预期中缺少的是干预措施。对我们行动的结果抱有期望是不够的；我们还必须对我们采取这些行动的能力抱有期望。

再次考虑我们的锻炼示例。班杜拉认为，仅仅关注我们对结果的期望（锻炼改善我们健康的可能性）是不够的。我们还必须检查我们对采取行动的能力的期望（我们是否相信我们可以坚持我们的锻炼计划）。前者可能足够高，足以证明成本的合理性，但如果后者较低，我们就会陷入低动力。

班杜拉是这样表述的：

自我效能有助于解释为什么即使我们想要一个结果，我们也可能不会努力实现它：

  • 这不仅是我们毕业的愿望，也是我们相信自己有能力学习这些材料的信念。
  • 我们不仅渴望拥有一家企业，而且相信我们能够使其成功。
  • 这不仅仅是我们对建立关系的渴望，而是我们相信我们可以约某人出去而不被拒绝。

班杜拉的理论改进了理性预期，因为它认为想要一个结果并不足以激励你采取行动；您还必须对自己采取必要行动实现这一结果的能力充满信心。

关于自我效能感的常见困惑

在解释自我效能的一些含义之前，我想澄清一下自我效能不是什么：

  • 自我效能不是自尊。自尊是你如何评价自己。自我效能是指您相信自己能够成功采取特定的行动方针。你可以相信自己很出色，同时也相信自己无法学习量子力学。
  • 自我效能不是自我概念。自我概念是你如何看待自己。自我效能是关于你如何看待自己执行一组给定行动的能力。
  • 自我效能不是自信。正如班杜拉所解释的那样，“信心是一个不起眼的术语，指的是信念的强度，但不一定具体说明确定性是什么。我非常有信心，我的努力一定会失败。”

自我效能感可能是一种学术理论，但我们对这个概念都有一些经验。我们可以回忆起我们对自己的能力感到自信的情况，以及我们严重怀疑自己能否成功的情况。我们直接了解这些信念对我们动机的影响。

班杜拉的贡献不仅仅是标记这种常见的经历，还为理解我们的动机提供了重要的启示。

是什么导致了自我效能感

班杜拉的研究发现，自我效能感有四个主要调节因素。

前两个是弱调节者——它们的影响可能很小，但并不可靠：

  1. 身体的兴奋。想想因怯场而出现的手心出汗和心跳加速的情况，或者在大考前出现的恶心感。这些会让你更难表现，即使你本来可以处于放松的状态。
  2. 口头劝说。当你完成比赛时，人群欢呼。老师告诉你你可以做到。简单地肯定你能或不能做某事会影响自我效能感，但这种影响是不可靠的。

与这些较弱的影响相反，班杜拉发现了两个更一致的自我效能来源：

  1. 替代经验。见证某人执行任务可以提高自我效能。首先，这为我们提供了一种学习有效策略的方法：如果我看到有人解决难题，我可以复制他们的方法以获得相同的结果。还有一个励志片段：如果我看到另一个蜘蛛恐惧症的人触摸狼蛛，我可能也会有勇气这样做。
  2. 个人掌握。个人经历一项任务（或类似的事情）的成功是提高自我效能的最有力的工具。跑完半程马拉松后，我会更有信心跑马拉松。在我的入门编程课程取得好成绩后，我会更有信心成为一名软件开发人员。

自我效能感强的人很可能拥有大量的替代经验和自我超越经验，因此，他们有很高的动力去实现宏伟的目标。

自我效能感的非明显影响

虽然自我效能感是众所周知的，但该理论的含义并不总是显而易见。

以下是该理论的一些重要推论：

1. 动力源自成功。

因为个人掌控力对于建立自我效能至关重要，所以在开始努力时一连串的失败更有可能使人失去动力，而不是增强勇气。

这是否意味着最好的激励方式就是只体验成功？不完全的。正如班杜拉本人所说：

绩效成就提供了最可靠的功效期望来源，因为它们基于个人的个人经历。成功提高了掌握的期望；反复的失败会降低它们，特别是如果事故发生在事件过程的早期。通过反复的成功形成强烈的功效预期后，偶尔失败的负面影响可能会减少。事实上，偶尔的失败，后来通过坚决的努力克服，可以通过经验增强自我激励的毅力，即使是最困难的障碍也可以通过持续的努力来克服。因此，失败对个人效能的影响部分取决于失败发生的时间和总体经历模式。一旦确定，功效预期往往会推广到相关情况。

如果你的自我效能感较低，它有助于为成功奠定基础。一旦你建立了基本的自信，将挑战与偶尔的挫折结合起来有助于增强自我效能感。你会发现，即使面对暂时的困难，你也能成功。

2. 信心螺旋可以上升，也可以下降。

自我效能的数学形成了一个正反馈循环。考虑：

  1. 您有一定的自我效能感，这使您能够采取行动并取得成果。
  2. 采取行动所取得的成功会提高你的自我效能感。
  3. 下一次，你就会更有动力去采取之前的行动。
  4. 重复。

最终，你的动机将稳定在理性预期理论所暗示的水平上（这就是为什么即使我们非常有信心的一些任务，比如洗碗，也不会激发狂喜的动机的原因之一）。

相反，当我们的自我效能感降低时，动力也会崩溃：

  1. 你有一定的自我效能感，并采取行动，但你未能跟进或完全完成行动。
  2. 没有达到预期的结果会降低你的自我效能感。
  3. 下次，你采取先前行动的动力就会减少。
  4. 重复。

当完全抑制采取所需行动时，这种动机螺旋式上升。对于任何尝试过几次新的追求、绊倒然后发现很难或厌恶再次解决问题的人来说，这种效果都很熟悉。低自我效能可能是我们陷入的陷阱。

3.向他人学习，成就自己。

自我效能只是班杜拉更广泛的社会学习理论的一部分。在其中，他认为我们所知道的大部分知识都来自其他人，并且我们通过目睹他人的行为来学习如何做大多数事情，而不是通过我们自己的反复试验。

这表明，建立自我效能感的一个关键方法是密切研究那些在你关心的事业上取得成功的人——看看他们是如何做到的，直到你了解他们正在采取的行动以及原因。他们的成功并不神秘；这是他们做出的一系列决定和采取的行动的逻辑结果。

如果你将这种仔细的学习方法与自己采取相同的行动结合起来，你就会使用班杜拉确定的两个最强大的杠杆来提高你的自我效能，从而提高你为具有挑战性的目标而努力的动力。

资料来源：
班杜拉、阿尔伯特.自我效能感：控制力的运用。纽约：WH Freeman and Company，1997。

班杜拉、阿尔伯特.社会学习理论。恩格尔伍德悬崖：Prentice-Hall, Inc.，1977 年。

; https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/2023/10/10/self-efficacy/feed/ 0 我给 18 岁的自己上的 18 条人生教训https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/2023/10/03/18-life-lessons/ https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/2023/10/03/18-life-lessons/#respondScott Young Tue, 03 Oct 2023 22:19:28 +0000General https://www.scothyoung.com/blog/?p=15475

由于我现在的年龄是我开始写这个博客时的两倍，我想我应该花一些时间来反思我希望我能给年轻时的自己的建议。

《我给 18 岁的自己上的 18 堂人生教训》一文首先出现在Scott H Young上。

;

我在距离 18 岁还有几个月的时候开始写这个博客。由于我现在的年龄是刚开始时的两倍，我想我应该花一些时间来反思我希望我能给年轻时的自己的建议。

1.如果你努力放松而不是自信，你的约会会更成功。

大多数给年轻人的约会建议都很糟糕。最容易被误解的建议之一是“表现得自信”。当你不自信时假装自信通常会让你看起来像个混蛋或小丑。相比之下，真正自信的人往往会放松。

2. 与交换生交朋友。

平均而言，那些故意选择在国外生活一年的人比那些对这种经历不感兴趣的人更有趣。交换生也往往希望交朋友。 （这也是获得更多机会应用第 3 课的好方法。）

3. 尽可能接受拜访朋友的邀请。

被当地人带去参观比当游客要好得多。如果您与来自非旅游胜地的人交朋友，则更是如此。

4.学习如何做饭。

我花了很多年的时间吃难吃的食物，因为我不知道如何做好饭菜。补救措施是在网上查找食谱并严格遵循它们。一旦掌握了基础知识，您最终就可以即兴发挥。

5.优化大学期间的经历，而不是成绩。

我在大学里最大的错误是在国外的那一年选择用英语而不是法语上课。我担心自己的学业跟不上，所以我选择了更容易的选择。我没有意识到我也错过了学习语言的最佳方法。

6、多参加聚会，少喝酒。

饮酒带来的享受收益大大递减，而且宿醉也不好玩。因此，如果您打算参与，请选择严格的截止日期，并在达到该金额时停止。您将享受更多的聚会，同时减少头痛。

7. 学会区分具有挑战性的情况和有毒的情况，并且不要因为放弃后者而感到内疚。

你不会后悔坚持艰巨的挑战，但你会后悔在你的价值观与你被要求做的事情不一致的情况下让自己筋疲力尽。

8. 学会识别混蛋并拒绝与他们打交道。

混蛋通常看起来很酷、很成功或者很重要。从短期来看，你通常会觉得你应该容忍他们的个性，以进一步实现你的目标。但从长远来看，你几乎总是会后悔没有早点摆脱它们。

9. 永远不要和一个你不会成为朋友的人约会。

当人们被一个人的表面特征所吸引时，很容易忽视个性差异。但这些关系很少能成功。我和我的妻子现在已经在一起九年了，在此之前我们只是朋友八年。

10.避免过早优化。

当你年轻且身无分文时，一份薪水很高的工作（对你来说）可能非常有吸引力。不幸的是，如果这份工作不能帮助你培养你在中年时会关心的技能，那么你最好拒绝一份低薪工作的机会。虽然你需要钱来生活，但要抵制住提早兑现的诱惑。

11. 作为一个成年人，变得（有点）怪异是可以的。

高中强制实行异常高程度的服从。在高中，即使是“奇怪”的孩子也倾向于服从某个特定的派系，而不是真正有趣。然而，在高中之外，稍微与众不同的惩罚就会减少，而且潜在的好处也更大，因为有更多的潜在朋友，他们的兴趣可能与你的兴趣重叠。

12. Don't waste your electives on “easy” classes.

Depending on your major, you may only have a handful of classes that you can choose for yourself. Don't waste these! Take interesting classes from different departments rather than the easy-A class that teaches you Microsoft Word.

13. Spend less time on your computer and more time at in-person events.

It's even better if those events have nothing to do with your current friends or interests. Bulk-positive randomness is a powerful force, but it can't move you if you stay inside your dorm room.

14. Ask yourself what a more extraverted version of you would do, and then do that.

Introversion is great when you're settled into a job and family life. But when you're young, exploring the maximum possible options for your future is important, so striving to be a more extraverted version of yourself is generally desirable.

15. Travel as much as you can.

Yes, traveling can be expensive. But you'll never be able to travel as cheaply, or have as many interesting experiences, as you can when you're young.

16. Press your clothes, comb your hair and wash your face.

I'll admit my appearance has never been something I've thought a lot about. But getting the basics right is usually not too onerous, and they matter a lot more for how people see you than how much money you spend on your clothes or how much you work out at the gym.

17. Don't be so dogmatic.

I've softened in many ways as I've gotten older. While youthful intensity about beliefs, goals or projects can be incredibly valuable, it can also get in the way of having new experiences. It's better to avoid being too rigid when you don't yet know which ideas of yours really ought to be inviolable.

18. Call your parents more often.

Since becoming a father, I've come to appreciate my own parents in a way that would have been difficult to understand as an eighteen-year-old. While it's easy to get absorbed in your own new experiences of adulthood, it's worth taking some time to keep up the relationships that have been with you all your life.

What advice would you give your younger self? Any agreements/disagreements with my list? Share your thoughts in the comments!

The trick for most ambitious pursuits, I'm afraid, is simply doing the obvious thing much, much more than most other people are willing to do—and accepting that it may hurt at times.

The post The Simple Rule for Achieving Ambitious Goals appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

Economist Bryan Caplan has advice for those who want to succeed at ambitious goals :

When I see the contrast between people who succeed and fail, I generally witness a similar gap in effort. During my eight years in college, I spent many thousands of hours reading about economics, politics, and philosophy. Since high school, I've spent over ten thousand hours writing. When young people ask me, “How can I be like you?“ my first thought is, again, do ten times as much .

Ten times as much of what, exactly? The answer is usually: Whatever you already think the crucial ingredient is. “Why can't I get ahead in my career? I strive to study and emulate my role models.” Great idea; you just need to multiply your effort by a factor a ten. “How can I save my marriage? I'm really trying to make my spouse happy.” Again, great idea. You just need to multiply your effort by a factor of ten.

The 10x Rule has helped me personally.

When I was gearing up to promote my book, Ultralearning, I asked for advice from James Clear, author of the mega best-seller, Atomic Habits . I knew podcasts were important for promotion, but I figured a dozen would suffice.

I asked James how many podcasts he went on. He told me he recorded 80 before the book launched and 200-300 in the first six months after its release.

Doing ten times as much of what you think works doesn't sound like mind-blowing advice. But it's startling to me how often the solution to whatever life problem you're facing is simply doing more to solve it.

Do the Obvious Thing First

Zvi Mowshowitz writes about data collected on dating from singles who want to be in a relationship. From this group, the most typical number of dates they had been on in the past year was one .

Zvi elaborates:

I am not saying that dating is easy or that I found it to be easy. I will go ahead and say it is not once-a-year level hard for most people to find worthwhile first dates.

What I especially find curious is that one is the most popular response rather than zero. It would make sense to me that the answer is frequently zero dates, because you are not trying and aren't 'date ready' in various senses. What's super weird is that the vast majority did go on the one first date, but mostly they didn't go on a second, and only half of those went on a third. It is as if people are capable of getting a date, then they go on one and recoil in 'oh no not that again' horror for about a year, then repeat the cycle? Or their friends set them up every year or so because it's been too long, or something? None of that makes sense to me.

If you're lonely and want to be in a relationship, the solution is obvious: get out, meet more people, ask them on dates and brush yourself off when you face rejection or heartbreak. Worrying about your height, weight, looks, or bank account is a distraction if you won't surmount the basic hurdle of putting yourself in more potentially-romantic contact with other people.

I could draw a similar lesson from my language learning experiences : the best techniques don't matter if you're not using the language enough. The secret to Vat and my success with the No English Rule wasn't exceptional talent or some magic of immersion. It's because when you commit to only speaking in the language you're learning, you end up practicing 10x as much.

Becoming a better writer is another example. I occasionally get emails from people who have started new blogs and want critiques of their writing. Invariably, they've written a handful of posts. I believe you shouldn't worry about technique until you've written at least one hundred essays. If you're not doing that much, finessing the method is pointless. I was at least a thousand essays in before my writing career took off, and I suspect I'm not an outlier.

The Trick is Not Minding That It Hurts

In a scene in Lawrence of Arabia , the titular TE Lawrence lights a cigarette and puts out the match by rubbing it between his fingers. Shortly after, another man attempts the same trick:

Man: Oh! [burning his fingers] It damn well hurts!

Lawrence: Certainly it does.

Man: Well what's the trick then?

Lawrence: The trick, William Potter, is not minding that it hurts.

The trick for most ambitious pursuits, I'm afraid, is simply doing the obvious thing much, much more than most other people are willing to do—and not minding that it's hard at times.

The three ingredients needed to apply deliberate practice to your career.

The post The Key to Building Rare and Valuable Skills appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

In the last three lessons, I've discussed the importance of focusing on the career capital that drives people's success , the logic of supply and demand that explains why rare and valuable skills matter so much , and the crucial importance of correctly identifying the path forward so you don't burn yourself out working on the wrong things .

Today, I'd like to shift and talk about how you can get good at the skills you need to flourish in your career.

Anders Ericsson and the Legacy of Deliberate Practice

Listen to this article

Few psychologists contributed more to the study of expertise than Anders Ericsson . His work studying world-class performance began with a simple memory study.

Digit-span tasks have long been a staple in cognitive psychology research. These are simple tasks where a subject is presented with a list of numbers and then asked to recall as many as they can remember. A famous finding from this type of task is that most people can recall between five and nine digits .

Typically, subjects get little practice on this task. Ericsson, however, worked with a single subject and repeated the same task over many sessions. The result? The subject's digit span exploded—he could recall over 100 digits at the end of their long training sessions.

In this particular subject's case, he invented a mnemonic system using running times (he was an avid runner) to recall far more digits than his memory would typically allow.

This experience led Ericsson to a long career studying the effects of large quantities of focused practice on human performance. Experts of all stripes, from doctors to musicians, can achieve things that would overwhelm the minds of novices through these sustained efforts.

Ericsson's research was a crucial inspiration for Cal Newport and me when we began working on Top Performer . Given the connection between world-class skills and an excellent career, we were interested in seeing how this model of deliberate practice could apply outside of the laboratory, tennis court, or music conservatory—how it could apply to professional areas where such practice efforts weren't the norm.

Applying Deliberate Practice to the Office

There are three basic ingredients to acquire any complex skill:

  1. You need to understand how the skill works. This mostly comes from learning from other people's examples, so you're not reinventing the wheel and are using current best practices.
  2. You need a lot of practice. Practice lets you perform skills more quickly and automatically. Ericsson's obsession with deliberate practice stemmed from the seeming removal of a hard psychological limit on human performance, just by practicing a lot.
  3. You need corrective feedback. Understanding how a skill works and doing it a lot is generally insufficient to get extremely good—corrective feedback that identifies what you're doing wrong and offers a replacement is usually needed to continue to improve.

Ericsson's definition of deliberate practice involves focused training sessions away from the demands of productive work. In these sessions, you would pay attention to a key aspect of your performance. Coaching would almost always be required because, otherwise, it's hard to get adequate corrective feedback.

Such a definition of deliberate practice makes a lot of sense in tightly controlled, high-performance domains such as chess, music or athletics. But what do you do to get better when your job is, as one former Top Performer student put it, “to basically answer emails all day?”

Designing a Deliberate Practice Project

Professional skills in real environments are not the same as highly-controlled variables in laboratory studies. Thus, when building rare and valuable career skills, getting the exact kind of deliberate practice Ericsson identified as crucial for world-class skill development is often difficult.

At the same time, we need to avoid the trap of simply accumulating seniority if we want to accelerate our careers. Many practitioners, even ones with years of experience, aren't exceptionally proficient. Despite years of experience, their skills can stop progressing if they lack a suitable training environment.

Cal and my solution to this dilemma in Top Performer was to guide students in designing a deliberate practice project. This type of project combines a few elements:

  1. It should be focused and specific—not just routine work , but something “extra” that will force your skills to a higher level.
  2. You should have an opportunity to study from examples to see how the best do it . Figuring out everything on your own is slow, so a good project begins with a clear picture of how the skill you're trying to improve works.
  3. You should be able to get clear feedback that can drive your progress.

Designing a good project is not trivial. You need to find something that is a good fit for the career capital you want to develop. Then, you need to focus your project so that improvement is possible—while keeping it relevant to your working life. Finally, you need to do the work. Each step has its challenges.

However, as we've seen with past cohorts from Top Performer, students can succeed with these kinds of projects, and their newly developed skills help them make strides in their work. Students have used projects to land new jobs, get promotions and raises, and become better at their professional craft.

I hope you've enjoyed this lesson series drawn from our course, Top Performer . In the full eight-week program, we go into much more detail on how to build a career you love. I hope you'll consider joining us for our next session!

Here are the best career research strategies to make sure you are not heading down a dead-ends with your deliberate practice efforts.

The post Before You Burn Yourself Out Working, Do This appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

In the previous two lessons, I shared why you should pay attention to successful people's career capital rather than their personal quirks when trying to emulate their achievements. Next, I applied the economic model of supply and demand to understand why some people are able to negotiate great career perks —money, autonomy, flexibility—while others are not.

Career capital, particularly rare and valuable skills, is the starting point for finding work you love. But how do you get them?

A tempting answer is simply to work hard. While it's true that success requires hard work and most successful people tend to be hard workers, working hard does not guarantee success.

While it's nearly impossible to build rare and valuable skills without hard work, tons of people work hard but still don't have great career capital. As a result, despite their great work ethic, they don't get the same perks that true top performers do.

Cal and My First Lesson from 8+ Years of Top Performer

Listen to this article

You avoid this trap by building skills that result in useful career capital, so the nuts and bolts of how to build these skills were on Cal Newport's and my mind as we began working on the first iterations of our course, Top Performer .

We already had an idea about how people build skills—Anders Ericsson, the psychologist who pioneered the concept of deliberate practice, spent decades studying the mental efforts needed to master difficult skills. Focused practice sessions, particularly under the supervision of a coach, can make all the difference in whether your skills will grow or stagnate.

However, when we ran our first sessions for the course, we noticed something different: Most people had no idea which skills they needed to build!

Worse, many people seemed to gravitate towards skills tangential to what really would make a difference. People seemed keen to improve skills that were fun to work on—an effortful project (but not too hard) so they could feel they were doing something to improve, but they weren't working on what mattered most.

There's nothing wrong with learning things for fun. But this approach can be counterproductive if your aim is to build career capital. You can spend months improving a skill that isn't directly related to what employers, clients or customers really want.

There are No Short-Cuts, But Plenty of Dead-Ends

Realizing that many people were heading down dead-ends with their deliberate practice efforts, Cal and I adjusted our next iteration of the course: Before getting into intensive skill-building work, we had the students research how their career path actually worked. Once they understood this, they better understood which projects would move them in the right direction—and which ones were a waste of time.

Doing this kind of research is tricky. Most of what you need to know is too specific to be written down in a book or article, so a trip to the library or a web search often comes up short. Instead, you need to talk to people. Yet talking to people who've achieved success can be equally frustrating! Even people who have amassed a surprisingly specific set of skills often shrink back to generic platitudes about the value of hard work when asked how they did it.

However, doing this research properly is essential. Knowing the path before you start walking it helps you avoid common traps people fall into when building their career:

  1. Getting a master's degree that nobody cares about.
  2. Working on technical skills when you need people skills.
  3. Not finding the right way to present your skills on your resume.
  4. Not recognizing which jobs are career-building opportunities and which are dead-ends.

After working with many students over the years, Cal and I found that the best people to talk to for this advice are 2 to 3 steps ahead of you in the career direction you're considering. These people have recently moved up, so their information is up-to-date and fresh in their mind.

Once you find and contact these people, you need to get them to tell you how they got where they are—which is surprisingly diffcult. Early on, Cal and I found that our students were simply asking those people for advice. While this seems like the obvious move, it almost never works. Instead of asking directly, you need to act like a journalist covering the story of this person's career transition—figure out the where, when, what and why of how they made the career leap you're currently contemplating.

These two actions, finding people 2 or 3 steps ahead of you in your career and interviewing them to figure out exactly what they did (not just the advice they want to share), help you narrow down which elements of your career capital you need to invest in and which you can ignore going forward.

In the next and final lesson, I'll share my thoughts on moving beyond identifying valuable skills to actually getting good at them. After that, Cal and I will be opening Top Performer for a new session. If the ideas I've been sharing have resonated with you, I think you'll enjoy the full course where we put them into practice.

In the last lesson , I explained why focusing on irrelevant details obscures the true driver of professional success: career capital.

But the connection between career capital and a great career isn't always obvious. Why does the owner of a car dealership tend to make more than a nurse or a teacher? Why would most people struggle to make a living as an artist, but the guy who put a taxidermied shark in a tank is worth nearly half a billion dollars?

The basic answer of whether you'll have a great career can be understood in terms of the simple economic concept of supply and demand.

Supply-and-Demand Thinking Applied to Your Working Life

Listen to this article

Let's start with demand.

Economists draw a downward-sloping curve to represent how much of something people want for a given price. The vertical axis is how much something costs, and the horizontal axis is how many people are willing to pay for the thing at each price. All else being equal, fewer people are willing (or able) to pay for something when the price is higher.

This curve can be a useful way to think about the value you offer to other people. In the job market, your career capital is valuable if people are willing to pay more for it. A higher-value set of career capital can be represented by the demand curve shifting to the right—more people want someone with your career capital for any particular price.

But demand isn't the whole story. Water is essential for life, diamonds are not. But water is cheap because the supply of water is plentiful, and diamonds are expensive because the supply of diamonds is scarce.

Similarly, the supply curve for your career can be envisioned as the number of people who are willing to supply that career capital (the horizontal axis) for a particular wage (the vertical axis). As the price goes up, more people are willing to supply those skills, connections, reputation and other assets that people want.

The supply curve can also be a measure of the scarcity of your particular career capital. Teachers and nurses earn less than many car dealership owners because there are more people who have the career assets to teach children or work as nurses than own big lots that can sell lots of cars.

In a normally functioning market, the intersection between the demand and supply curves reflects the price and quantity sold of a given product. If demand is high and the supply is low, the price goes up.

In a career context, the return on your career capital depends on how many people value it, and how many others can supply it. This means to have a good career position, you need assets that are both rare and valuable.

This thinking applies beyond just how much money you make. The person with rare and valuable career assets can, of course, parlay that into a higher income. But those same assets also serve as a negotiating point for anything else you might want: vacation time, interesting projects, professional autonomy, and more. A career you love and a career that pays well may not always be the same thing, but they're both made possible with rare and valuable career capital.

As a mental model, I find supply-and-demand thinking incredibly useful, but it ignores a lot of important factors. Price caps, monopsonistic employers, professional guilds restricting membership, and more all complicate this basic model. However, it's still a good baseline for thinking about the kind of career you can have.

Building Rare and Valuable Skills

As discussed in the previous lesson, skills are often the best starting point for building career capital. Reputation and connections tend to follow, not precede, excellent work, so the best place to start is building the skills that support doing excellent work.

This view reframes the question from how to build a valuable career to: How do you acquire rare and valuable skills?

This was the opening question Cal and I posed when we first started building our course, Top Performer . In the coming two lessons, I'll share two major findings from working on this issue with thousands of students over nearly a decade. We're setting up for a new session, starting next week. If you're interested in building the career capital that actually drives a great career, I hope you'll join us.

Why do we obsess over irrelevant personality quirks, instead of what really drives a person's success?

A pet peeve of mine is self-help advice that obsesses over irrelevant personality quirks rather than the true drivers of a person's success.

  • Hedge fund billionaire Ray Dalio meditates forty minutes per day .
  • Tim Ferriss wrote his bestselling books between 10 pm and 5 am .
  • Warren Buffett famously drinks five cans of Coca-Cola every day .
  • And so on …

There isn't any secret diet, exercise, meditation or journaling exercise that will make you successful. Warren Buffett isn't rich because of his junk food diet; he's rich because he is an incredibly skilled investor who has worked continuously for nearly eight decades.

What Really Drives Successful Careers

Listen to this article

Look, there's nothing wrong with daily meditation, finding your most productive time to work or drinking colas. (Okay, maybe that last one isn't so great … )

Instead, my misgiving with this kind of advice is that it's focused on behaviors that are, at best, indirectly related to a person's career success. Maybe Ray Dalio is right, and meditation makes him more productive—or maybe he's just really good at being a hedge fund manager.

A better way to analyze the drivers of success among top performers is to examine their career capital. These are the assets they have that directly produce value for their employers, clients or customers:

  1. 技能。 If you can do work few other people can, or you can do it better than most people, you have a powerful bargaining chip when looking for work. People with rare and valuable skills can set off bidding wars in negotiations, whereas people with mediocre levels of common skills usually cannot.
  2. 连接。 Relationships can also be an asset. A journalist with a long career can often get a book deal, not only because she's spent years honing her writing skills, but also because she knows tons of people throughout the publishing industry who can talk about her book.
  3. Reputation. How do you choose which products to buy? Chances are you don't buy each possible option and test them at home before returning all but your favorite. Instead of relying on reviews, you pick brands that are high-quality for their price range and ask people you know. The same is true when people hire you.

Career capital explains success in a way that incidental habits cannot. While it's easy to find examples of people who attribute their success to a particular behavioral quirk, it's also easy to find plenty of cases where people with the same behavior don't achieve such success.

In contrast, if someone has a successful career, they're virtually guaranteed to have a lot of career capital.

How to Build Career Capital

Career capital comes in different flavors, and we've already discussed three: skills, connections and reputation.

Among these assets, skill tends to come first. 1

Connections are nice if you're born into a wealthy family, or went to an elite private school and have a great network. But if you don't, knocking on the doors of random successful people, hoping they'll be your friend and help you out, is not a strategy most people can pull off.

More commonly, connections follow from doing good work. When you make a name for yourself as being excellent at what you do, people will want to get to know you.

Similarly, reputation often matters more than raw ability. But, as with connections, reputation is a natural by-product of doing excellent work. Reputation follows skill, not the other way around.

Skills also have the benefit of being trainable. While good looks, family money or famous friends may be valuable career assets, they're not always accessible if you don't stumble into them.

Anyone can improve their portfolio of skills that can improve their career.

When is laziness smart? Why does the thinking behind being productive often feel like we're being tricked into working more?

The post The Efficiency Mindset appeared first on Scott H Young .

;

Our deepest beliefs are often girded by assumptions we rarely articulate. The mindset of efficiency is one of mine.

The assumptions of this mindset are essentially:

  1. There are things we want.
  2. We can take actions to get the things we want.
  3. Some actions are more efficient than others—ie, they will get more of what we seek for less time, effort, money, etc.
  4. The resources we save by being more efficient can be spent on other things we want.

To consider a concrete example, think of a task like studying for an exam:

  1. There is something you want: to pass the exam and learn the material.
  2. There are actions you can take to get what you want: studying.
  3. Some actions are more efficient than others: some methods of studying result in more learning than others.
  4. If you use more efficient methods to save time studying for the exam, you can put that time toward other activities you enjoy.

The efficiency mindset applies broadly because these assumptions apply to many things. But it's also important to note where they break down.

Where Does the Efficiency Mindset Break Down?

A common criticism of the efficiency mindset is rooted in an overly-narrow interpretation of assumption #1, the things you want.

Consider speed reading a novel. This is “efficient” in the sense that you're getting through the book in less time. But is that really what you want?

Much of the value in reading a novel comes from enjoying the plot, dwelling in the world of the characters, or pondering the book's deeper meanings.

When efficiency often fails, it is usually because we've adopted an overly restrictive, incomplete, or inaccurate view of what's valuable about the activity.

While this is a wrinkle in applying the efficiency mindset, it's not a compelling argument against it. If you incorporate all the things you value, appropriately weighted, then the efficiency mindset still works. It's essential to include things like “enjoyment” and other often-overlooked values when considering the efficiency of reading novels.

The real failure of efficiency isn't an overly narrow conception of what we desire, but when assumption #4, that you can reinvest resources saved by being more efficient, breaks down.

When Working Harder Only Creates More Work

Central to the efficiency mindset is the idea that the time or resources saved through efficiency are fungible. You need to be able to take the time, money or effort saved on doing one thing and apply that to something else. If you can't reinvest the resources, doing things more efficiently doesn't pay off.

As a teenager, I worked at a video rental store one summer. Being more efficient working at the store was kind of pointless. The boss would exhort employees to spend idle time cleaning the shelves or tidying the display racks, but people seldom did. When the store wasn't busy, we just lounged around. When there were tasks to be done, nobody was in a hurry to finish them quickly.

The fact that nobody (except maybe the manager) thought about efficiency made total sense. Working harder didn't pay off. Our hours were set, we earned minimum wage, and there weren't performance bonuses for extra effort. Nobody was angling for a promotion or hoping to move up the video-rental corporate ladder. If you finished your work early, there was only more busy work. You didn't get to do anything more interesting with the time saved.

Additionally, in that environment, working more efficiently was socially costly. Hanging out with the other staff was the only glimmer of joy in an otherwise mindless job, so if you became the person who got everything done with speed, you made your other coworkers look bad.

I'm sure management's perspective was that we were all just lazy. We were paid to be there and work, so why didn't we work as hard as possible? But from our perspective, as long as we met our actual job requirements, there was no reason to be any more efficient.

I sometimes think about those days because my current life is worlds apart. I'm my own boss, and my income, free time and personal success depend entirely on my efficiency. However, I'm also aware that if you're used to environments with no reason to be efficient, “efficiency” is just a byword for what the boss wants you to do.

Efficiency is a Novel Concept

I mention that experience because across different cultures and social organizations throughout human time, I think the situations where it paid to be efficient were relatively rare.

I can't find the source now, but I recall reading a book where Western researchers came to investigate a remote tribe that engaged in some subsistence agriculture. The tribespeople surveyed often complained about being hungry, wanting more food. But, to the investigator's eyes, they seemed, well … kinda lazy. They didn't do what seemed obvious to the anthropologists, simply growing more crops so they'd have more to eat.

The authors claimed this had to do with the social organization they lived in. Supposing you did grow a surplus of food, you could eat as much as you want. But in the close-knit band you lived in, sharing was required. So distant relatives who were hungry would complain to you to give them some of your food. The industrious subsistence farmer wouldn't have much incentive to work hard since any surplus would likely be taken away.

As this is beginning to sound like a cloaked libertarian allegory, I think it's worth pointing out that even in societies with strong social welfare states and progressive redistribution policies, we still get to keep most of the fruits of our labor.

Instead, the point I'm trying to make is that the benefits of efficiency are a rather unusual feature of modern societies and that, at most points in time, we were probably like the “lazy” subsistence farmers who couldn't see the point of being more efficient. If efficiency seems unnatural to us, it might be because, throughout our evolutionary history, working really hard to generate surplus wasn't often a sound strategy.

Are You Lazy, Or Is It Your Workplace?

Most environments we work in exist on a spectrum. At one end are the dead-end video rental jobs or tribal subsistence farmers where the idea of efficiency is alien and unrewarding. At another extreme are the scenarios where efficiency is obsessed over because any gains are personal rewards.

Work cultures exist on a spectrum too. I previously discussed an interesting description of Japanese office culture , which appears to prize working extreme hours at the office (with the result that employees are often terribly inefficient). On the other extreme are results-only work environments , where pay is exclusively based on performance (but that performance can be difficult to track and assess fairly).

I suspect that when productivity feels like a chore rather than an opportunity, it's less because we're intrinsically lazy and more because our environment makes us that way.
